summary: Young orphan Sheeta and her kidnapper, Col. Muska, are flying to a military prison when their plane is attacked by a gang of air pirates led by the matronly Dola. Escaping from a mid-air collision via a magic crystal around her neck, Sheeta meets fellow orphan Pazu and the pair join forces to discover the mystical floating city of Laputa while pursued by both Muska and the pirates, who lust for the city's myriad treasures.

reviews.content:
This movie is incredible! (In my opinion, the peak of Studio GHIBLI)  This film has stellar music, animation that still leaves you hungry for more, a very interesting, unique, and classic tale that never gets old!  A truly fantastic movie!
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! 11/10 STARS!

Note: For best viewing experience, view the original Japanese Dub!
LOL, the funniest 02 hours: and 04 minutes of anime, also known as Japanimation (or Japanese animation)!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Ohhh maaaa gooood... that was beautiful.
Well, kinda. Of course there were things I didn't like, but that's what makes this film great. 
It's so sad that humans are the real enemies. As soon as nature creates such power, humans want it to become powerful like a god. Can't we just once appreciate the nature and its treasure itself, without destroying it? I guess that's not possible. That's why Laputa needed to be gone for good. I just hope Laputa landed on some other planet, where the citizens treat it good, instead of wanting to rule over the world.
I loved the pirates the most, although they were a but annoying in the beginning.
Beautiful fantasy adventure, with the powerful statement that technology and nature can coexist peacefully.
A classic adventure story. In my opinion, Miyazaki's best.

I cannot begin to describe how much I love this film. I love Studio Ghibli, and Castle in the Sky is one of my absolute favourites from them. It has a highly imaginative story for starters, every bit as imaginative as Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind's. Once again, the animation is magnificent, as is the haunting and poignant music score. The dialogue and pacing are fine too, and the characters are never devoid of their likability and are wonderfully voiced by a top notch voice cast. Castle in the Sky is an absolutely beautiful film, but it is also quite haunting helped enormously by the music and visuals. It is an amazing and I think unforgettable film, one of the best animes, perhaps even animated movies I have seen. 10/10 Bethany Cox

There are many parts of the movie that keep me engaged. The music does great at capturing the whimsy of the story even in the darker parts of the film. The main antagonist, Colonel Muska, is voiced by Mark Hamill who does an amazing job to reflecting the cartoonishly evil bad guy hungry for power. He makes an intimidating presence and shows a vast contrast towards the more humorous nature of the soldiers and goofiness of the pirates. The children show a great bond and courage that you would expect from children in an 80s-early 90s fantasy adventure film like Hook or The NeverEnding Story. These characters help give this movie a very charming quality to it along with the steampunk aesthetics. Certain moments go darker than the theme of the film intends to go such as the physical violence on children and murder of large groups of people. This shows the lengths the antagonist will go but puts on a very aggressive tone in the process which can overshadow the quirkiness that has been shown by all the characters throughout the entire film. The anti-war themes and theme of nature conservation are still here like most of Miyazaki's works, but it is not as blatant as is seen in Howl's Moving Castle or Princess Mononoke. A great film for newcomers to Studio Ghibli and for those who love diving into 80's fantasy adventure nostalgia.
It's an excellent fairly tale animation by Hayao Miyazaki...

7 years ago- Set in a beautifully drawn world, the film chooses to show rather than tell about the strange airbourne world. While the plot drags at time, the Atlantis like tale is epic, helped by the voice talents of Leachman and Mark Hamill.
One of Ghiblis best movies!

Hayao Miyazaki is one of the most inspirational animators in the world. His stories are legendary, and he creates them with integrity, art, culture, wonder, and emotion while creating state of the art animation for every generation of movie goers to enjoy. CASTLE IN THE SKY is truly a must see for everyone.
A beautifully animated Ghibli film that is full of the whimsy and imagination that Miyazaki consistently brings to the table.

The best Ghibli film I've seen and actually enjoyable enough to sit through. This is where the ethereum coin got its name which is interesting and unexpected. Major downside is a brief moment of some elderly guys perving in a 13 year old girl. Very odd. Otherwise it's a nice kids classic.
Funny stuff, and impressive work too.

I've found I'm not a very good judge of quality for these Ghibli movies. It's hard to be objective about it as I lean toward comparing them to each other instead of sitting back and understanding that each one is a work of art in its own right. My viewing experience has been suffering from diminishing returns in that even though I'm only a few movies in I've come to expect the incredible creativity and detailed animation that all of them have had so far, and so I don't find myself as thoroughly impressed as the movie would normally warrant. I liked the plot of this one but I'm rather ambivalent to the whole steampunk aesthetic in general so I wouldn't consider this one my favorite. There were also quite a lot of lengthy silences that I found distasteful when they could've instead just made the movie shorter.
Cool animation, excellent music. I watched it like 10 times already since I was very young. My favourite movie of all time.
it's always grownup's endless craving for power that brings a catastrophe. only cure to that is pure respect for every living thing, and love. guess who has that? a normal innocent child.
A wonderful kid product though it's not near of any obsessed work of the skies. 5/10

Castle in the Sky is amazing! The animation is dreamy and the architecture is marvelous! It involves pirates, lost island, friendship, violence, and the military. I like the character development of the pirates going from being ruthless and greedy to caring but still maintaining some of their characteristics (for humor purposes). It's a cute story with a slight dystopian.

I've wanted to watch this movie for 20 years and finally got it. It's a masterpiece. I watched the English dub version. It really was a great time. To start, the movie scores were excellent.  Run time was lengthy but not tedious.  Not much to criticize about it.  If you appreciate good animated fantasy worlds and story's,  watch it
It was a good movie especially for it's time

Before "Laputa" I knew Ghibli only from "Totoro" and "Spirited Away", so stories of magical realism and going down the rabbit hole. I had no idea that even before that, in their first movie, they created a pure fantasy story with visible 19th century inspirations, and one that plays nearly exactly like our western young adult novels no less. This is an epic tale that perfectly suits my personal tastes (perhaps because it lacks and distinctly Japanese elements that are so popular in anime), has beautiful structural integrity and is somehow able to present such a rich collection of scenes and characters despite being no longer than two hours. But two hours is still a lot for an animated movie and I feel grateful that here they are filled perfectly with a story that resonates with me and with stunning visuals. The movie is worth seeing even only for the few ethereal, melancholic moments that it spends on the exploration of the titular castle in the sky that beam witch such still beauty unlike nearly anything that I have ever seen on screen. For me this outclasses both "Totoro" and "Spirited Away" and I just can't wait to check out other Ghibli offerings. Who knows what treasures I am still to find among them?

"Castle in the Sky" shows that Studio Ghibli had plenty of creativity and imagination even early on. This movie is whimsical and full of many exhilarating moments. I think in terms of entertainment, this is one of the most enjoyable and fun movies I have seen from the famous studio. I liked the story and appreciated the themes and think it is one of those movies adults and children can all enjoy together. I also really liked the score of the movie and it added a layer of excitement in some pivotal moments. Overall, it is an enjoyable and unique ride that is among the top half of the Studio Ghibli films that I have watched so far.
Gorgeously animated and beautifully told. One of Miyazaki's best.
yeah it good u should watch this

This movie is a masterpiece. 
It is Studio Ghibli at its best. The story is easy to understand but not too simple, the main characters are likable and all characters have distinct character designs that represent their personalities even. Laputa is an iconic and incredibly memorable location and the image of the robot soldiers stays in your mind forever. There's a lot of fun action sequences but also some quiet moments, which helps with the pacing a lot.
Speaking of pacing, the movie never feels too slow or too fast, its beautifully balanced.
The design and animation of the various technology used in the movie is excellent and creative. The backgrounds are beautiful and detailed, although they dont match newer Ghibli movies in detail. Laputa its self is designed perfectly.
The soundtrack of the movie is incredible. The music always fits each scene and the main theme is incredibly beautiful, almost unparalleled. Besides the flying castle with its robot soldiers, the Highlight of the movie is the releationship between the pirate captain and the two main characters Pazu and Sheeta combined with the excellent character development of the Pirate Captain, who almost becomes like a mother figure for the two.

Excellent movie, deserving of a perfect score.

Writing this review a couple days after watching the film I kinda forgot about it. I only remember the blue stone that the main girl had to awaken the robot people. And they of course win. I don't remember hating on this movie besides it being very predictable but I do like the animation and cool explosions specifically during the scene where the robot first shows up and tries to protect the main girl. That was pretty cool but everything else was pretty boring and predictable.

This was my fourth Miyazaki film that I have seen, and it is definitely up there with my favorites. It has so much heart to it and the world that Miyazaki creates is fantastic. This movie started out actually very promising. Halfway through though, it became quite dull and boring. I think it was because this movie really was not what I was expecting! I thought it would become more fantasy, and it turned out to be more action! There were pirates in the movie, and crystal digging, and this type of adventure isn't really my thing. It became very dull quickly! The friendships were cute, but cute isn't enough to make the cut!

What I liked most was the two main characters, and they have good relationship with each other. Also, the animation was great, with the Sky and the castle looking beautiful and immense. 

As for problems, the movie as a whole was pretty predictable, as well as some side characters. The story of the castle and civilization was not explored enough, even though the movie was pretty long. 

Overall, a pretty fun adventure movie. 7/10

A breezy emotional odyssey!

Hayao Miyazaki's romantic fantasy adventure Castle in the Sky (1986) is pure magic on film. Studio Ghibli's hand drawn animation is second to none. Castle in the Sky's mystical tone, emotional magic, deep blues, bright skies, puffy clouds, and touching story all make it one of the finest anime films ever crafted. I'm grateful to be able to appreciate and enjoy Miyazaki's vast imagination to have created this genius narrative all from his mind with heartfelt themes of peace, love, and understanding. His passion shows in his direction with all manner of aircrafts, ruins, robots, and magic crystals like only a lover of fantasy and creativity could muster. You can see Miyazaki's influence in other anime with the girl falling from the sky to the flying castle and so much more innovative animation. I adored Castle in the Sky and look forward to cherishing it forever.

Anna Paquin's voice acting in the English Dub is amazingly expressive for Sheeta. She delivers one of the greatest child voice acting recordings I've ever heard. She sounds heartbroken when the first robot dies and enthralled whenever she's speaking with her fellow adventurer boy Pazu. I found her accent adorable too coupled with her gentle tone. James Van Der Beek is immediately likable as Pazu with his endearing charm as the hard working boy, dreaming of flying to a castle in the sky to redeem his father's memory. He's really excellent and giving it his all with an excitable vocal performance.

Cloris Leachman's rambunctious elderly pirate leader Dola is a blast to hear and watch. Mark Hamill's evil role as the voice of Muska is fantastic. You feel his rage and hear his superior attitude towards all people below him. Uncle Pom's voice actor, Richard Dysart, did a wonderful job of making him sound gentle, yet knowledgeable. Jim Cummings does his usual booming voice for the greedy general. John Hostetter's grumpy voice is very pleasant for the old man boss. In short, Castle in the Sky has a phenomenally talented voice cast for the English Dub.

Hayao Miyazaki's direction is so focused and fun for this wild adventure full of an endearing little romance, goofy comedy with silly air pirates, hard commentary on military and federal greed, and general disgust at humanity's capabilities for arrogance in destroying nature for power. His writing is wonderfully inventive with a sci-fi penchant for airplanes and cybernetic cities. His people are grounded with a realism of hard labor with dreams of flying like we all have from time to time. I love how much Miyazaki treasures airships, gliders, automatons, and animals in his iconic anime films. Miyazaki's Castle in the Sky makes it easy to dream.

Hayao Miyazaki, Takeshi Seyama, Yoshihiro Kasahara's editing keeps Castle in the Sky moving at a frantic pace with chases quickly cut alongside massive explosions and swift aerial combat. It's 124 minutes of excitement, humor, romance, and mystery all in a briskly paced picture.

Similarly, Hirokata Takahashi's cinematography is expressive with large open wide shots of the sky to really ensure that it feels real and boundless. The way he shoots up close during certain fast flying sequences gives the feeling of their notable speed just like his wide shots allow the environment to feel real. All the background paintings for the vines, trees, and rubble look so vividly realized. Nizou Yamamoto and Toshio Nozaki's art direction is really spectacular for the floating castle, gritty warships, and mystical chambers with glowing crystals.

Joe Hisaishi's airy score is composed with sweeping majesty and gentle fondness. His sweet score for Castle in the Sky is as lovely as the film itself with powerful symphonic strings and tender piano melodies all over his music. I really loved just sitting back hearing moving music that just allows you to be nostalgic for childhood. 

If Miyazaki is good at anything, it's that his movies capture the sensation of childlike wonder when the city is first seen in a picture and then at the end for the finale. He grasps at the illusions of our dreams and wildest imagination, then transposes them on film. Castle in the Sky is wish fulfilment in the most satisfying way. All his mysteries are answered and the glow of the unknown is transformed into the breathtaking beauty of dreams being realized, friendships forming, and the loving warmth of romance evermore present in our heroes and in the audience alike.

In all, Castle in the Sky is immediately one of my absolute favorite Hayao Miyazaki feature films as well as a personal joy to watch. I hope you get to see it soon.
Great story as you might expect from Miyazaki. Not as deep or emotional as some of his other movies, but rather adventurous, funny and exciting .
It's a beautiful love story in the sky.

Another beautifully animated and high quality film from Miyazaki, with all of his characteristic elements - a young girl who is the 'chosen one', a young boy who may or may not be a love interest, incredible worldbuilding, a charismatic old woman, flying, and a mustachioed villain. This one may not be at the top of everyone's personal list of Ghibli films, but it is still an exceptional piece of filmmaking that only serves to solidify the studio's position as an all-time great in the medium. (4.5/5)

Watched it once, and plan on seeing it again. A magical movie, from early Ghibli. Miyazaki is downright amazing, one of the best ever in the animation industry. His work doesn't get the praise it demands.

The first half of the movie is very slow but once it gets going it's pretty good. It's got all the charm I expected from Studio Ghibli and the stakes never feel too high. Unfortunately Sheeta ends up being more of a plot device and less of a character - I think she might take one deliberate action the entire movie. The rest is just her being moved from place to place and everyone else doing things around her. It feels a bit misogynistic at times as traditional roles are forced upon her. The environmental allegories are pretty obvious but it's still a nice message. Since this is a classic Ghibli film I have to recommend it, but be sure to adjust your expectations for the time in which it was made.

I’m all for movies that do their best to show and not tell, but my big frustration with Castle in the Sky is that it seems to have adopted the philosophy of show and then tell. The movie starts off and I felt like I was jumping in the middle of a story, almost like I turned on episode 5 of a television series without seeing the 4 that came before. I kept hoping it would slow down for even a few minutes so I could get to know any of the characters. But it was almost 30 minutes or more before they even took a moment to establish their identities, and even longer before I managed to care about them at all. I think it was when they started to work on the pirate ship that I finally found myself laughing with them and enjoying the film. Even then I didn’t feel like the protagonists had much personality to them. It was almost like having two generic kids filling those main roles, and their only defining characteristics came from their situation rather than their personality traits. Then they hit the titular Castle in the Sky and everything stops. The exposition dump is excessive at this point of Castle in the Sky, and we aren’t allowed to figure out anything for ourselves. This is the inevitable moment in the Miyazaki movie where he gets onto his soapbox about anti-war and environmentalism, which always takes me out of the movie, particularly when it feels like all story-telling halts in order to make the point. Once the plot gets moving again, I was on board for the action sequences, and I enjoyed watching the heroes fight back against the villain. The climax was a bit predictable since they so blatantly foreshadowed it, but the journey to that epic conclusion was thrilling. One final note, I am usually all about watching these anime films with the English dubbing, because I think they get solid actors and make it work brilliantly, but Anna Paquin and James Van Der Beek basically ruin this one. I kind of despised their performances, and would recommend you watch the subtitled version instead, even though that means missing great work from the likes of Mark Hamill and Cloris Leachman. My final assessment of Castle in the Sky is lukewarm. I didn’t dislike it as much as most other Miyazaki films, but I wasn’t all that enamored with it either.
I don’t know man...It started slow, and it’s kinda slow, but as you may come to expect it’s pretty. Also so cool cultural stuff happening.
Finally got to see one of my all time favorites on the big screen. Masterpiece. No other way to describe it.

Laputa: The Castle in the Sky is the first Japanese anime I watched and also it's the only one I loved. When I saw this anime on a website, the reason why I decided was two main characters were kind of cute and lovely. So, I watched it and I loved it.

The story is not so simple and not so complicated. But because of the director, it turned out to be a good one. What I love about this anime is how Sheeta and the leader of those pirates became friends.

I don't like the castle though. The castle is kind of ruined. Maybe it's because it is ruined in the story. So, the anime creators did like that. But it still works.

The anime was produced in 1986 (way before I was born) but the quality is unbelievably good. I haven't a clue before I saw it's production year. When I saw it, I can't believe it because the anime is too good.

What I love most is the end credit song. That song is so cool.

All in all, for some people, the anime might be kind of inferior to those ones produced in 20th centuries but as for me, it's the best Japanese anime I've ever seen. It's totally worth spending time.

Air pirates, army and government agents wants to abduct Sheeta, a girl with mysterious necklace with crystal pendant. She meets boy by the name of Pazu who plans to construct a plane and set off in search for the flying city of Laputa. During the movie we learn that in the past mankind mastered the technology which enabled construction of flying cities, but after an unnamed disaster survivors continued to live on the ground. The story of this anime is very easygoing and tender, but at the same time it opens up very serious issues concerning the relationship of man and civilization towards nature, while rethinking the essence of modern development and what is usually accepted as progress.

It's easy to notice similarity between the shape of the central tree that dominates Laputa, a symbol of prosperity, harmony and security, and the atomic mushroom created by the main weapon of this flying city. On the example of Laputa we can expose fundamental contradictions of imperialism / world system: Laputa is a paradise for those who live in it (in the centre of the world system), while at the same time it's bringing destruction to those who live on the ground (on the periphery of the world system). Equally important contradiction can be also seen in relation of the civilization towards the planet: while we are hypocritically promoting recycling and separating the glass, plastic and paper, at the same time corporations annually cut down between three and six billion trees, without any serious social resistance or critique.

Laputa shows that harmful effects of technology are consequences of the choice of those who control the technology to use it in this way, or to simply ignore warnings and its harmful aspects. They appropriate benefits of technology for themselves, while transferring (externalizing) harm and problems to the rest of society. Miyazaki, the master of animation who grew up in postwar Japan, is careful not to opt for one of the sides in the false dilemma "technology or nature" and uses the metaphor of Laputa to construct a positive reference point against which we can critically observe our society.

The name Laputa comes from Swift's novel Gulliver's Travels, where exists a flying island of the same name whose residents use their technology for political domination. Political will for domination through technological superiority marked not only the twentieth century, but also of the previous millennia of civilization development. Laputa sends us the message that a sustainable civilization must renounce war as a way of life, and especially imperialism as inherently destructive social form. Laputa creates a longing in us to realise a balance between nature and technology - a society that will achieve symbiotic unity of the ecosphere and the technosphere.
Probably one of the best fantasy films of the 80s/90s.

This was the movie that started it all for Studio Ghibli, and it delivers on a high note with wonderful animation,great characters, and amazing storytelling. Castle in the Sky is a special treat for everyone.
Compared to Miyazaki's other films, this entertaining action-adventure is half as memorable but double as fun
So boring. Fell right to sleep

Castle in the Sky is exactly what you'd expect from a Miyazaki film. It features a bizarre storyline with surreal characters and beautiful animation. It's easy to get caught up in this world of flying cities and sky pirates and suspend your disbelief. It's a simple and magical story.
Another classic in the anime industry
This film was almost good.
One of my favourite movie. Beautiful story and visuals.

A young boy encounters a young girl who floats down from the sky and becomes involved with pirates, government agents and the search for a legendary floating castle. I love Miyazaki, but this is a film I like, but don't love. It's an immensely creative film and an often beautifully animated film, but it has a kind of wacky anime tone that I really dislike. It feels like a formative film that has a tone that's typical for the genre that none of his future work would have.
Castle in the sky tells an incredibly heart felt tale that you are sure to remember for the rest of your life.

One of Miyazaki's funniest and most entertaining films. Works with strong anti-war and peaceful leadership themes, although in the end does not quite reach the profundity achieved by some of his later films. It still stands as a beautiful experience.
A fun adventure story for anyone looking for the island in the sky.

So beautiful. Miyazaki movies are for kids, but they are capable of melting anyone's heart. They are encouraging, they teach a lot and they are not simple in their judgments. The question of the group of pirates who become so lovable throughout the film is an example of the Japanese's ability to create characters without destiny, without being totally good or evil, only human. The story unfolds very well, although it has a few moments of slip. A wonderful film, but one that must be watched in Japanese because the American dubbing is horrible.
A wonderful story with great characters and some sadly dated animation.
Studio Ghibli never disappoints!!! Wonderful movie!
This was a great movie

While it may not be as effective as some of Miyazaki's masterpieces, Castle in the Sky is nonetheless a beautifully animated, creative, and enjoyable film that can be enjoyed by audiences of all ages.
so dark the con of man

Even before Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli was considered the international success, "Castle in the Sky" predicted that animation would become a domineering force in film industry. It has a balance between both kids and adults: a fun animated period piece with a subtle environmentalist message. The characters have a purpose, an ultimate twist, and the worldbuilding is almost as beautiful as a classic sci-fi film. Miyazaki has made a creative place to live in, and a wonderful epic to see.

A more action-oriented Miyazaki effort, Castle in the Sky has a few stunning sequences and some beautiful animation to offer, but ultimately fails where Studio Ghibli usually succeeds with flying colors- in the character and story departments
As always an excellent Studio Ghibli film!
Great story, great characters and a great story!
It may be because I loved this as a child, but it is a great film.

I have seen plenty of animated movies since the late 80s, but very few stand up to this film's originality and adventurousness. And why stop at animated movies? I mean, "Avatar" is fine and everything, but I'll take this. Miyazaki has a unique gift for storytelling (and characters). Watching movies like this with my kids has been a gift.

Love the ambiguous but intersting opening, it leaves one guessing what is really going on. I love how different and opposite the girl and the boy are, they make a good team. They're really cute together. This is a wonderful adventure movie. That old hag is fueled by greed, brute of a woman. But that guy with shades is just as bad if not worse.

Real beautiful that cave scene. It was like they were teleported to the center of the universe. That robot sure is really powerful. Intersting to see all these different groups of people who want the crystal. It's almost as if the crystal is too powerful for anyone to own it.

Great adventure of a movie! Reminds me a lot of Indiana Jones. That was funny how all the crew members were trying to help the girl because they were all falling for her.

Wow, Laputa is even more beautiful than I anticipated. It's like an oasis. Seeing the same little cat creature that was in Nausicaa, made me gasp. You can see that greed fuels evil and vice versa when the army arrives to Laputa and they start pillaging all the treasure. I'm glad it ended the way it did. No one should have all that power. There must be a balance.

Overall, this is an epic adventure movie with a great cast of characters.
The steampunk mix over an environmentalist theme comes off artistic instead of preachy and the score is phenomenal, really enjoyed this film.
Even amazing in English, though I still prefer it in Japanese.

this was a fantastic movie! Griping and interesting all throughout the film, a couple of twists that I didn't see coming ! Just a beautiful adventure story that really takes you on a journey! I would watch with me whole family!
It's sloppily written, but Studio Ghibli's debut feature, "Castle in the Sky," will be a pleasant diversion for those seeking beautiful animation.
I'm a Miyazaki fan and this was a great treat by Miyzaki.
This is one of my favorite of Miyazaki's films.

A beautifully animated and engaging film, it is definatly hurt by the English dub, not enough to detract from the magic of the visuals, but enough to wish it were a silent film. Must find a subtitled version and reevaluate.
One of Miyazaki's richest movies.
this is amazing now my favorite studio is studio ghibli

Miyazaki strikes again! This adventure of a young boy and girl looking for a forgotten kingdom is breath taking. The animation is wonderful and the voice casting (in english) is one of the few great Japanese to English translations that are great.

10 out of 10:

It's the visually stunning and breathtaking animation, charm, and sense of adventure that truly makes Castle in the Sky a masterpiece.

I recently first encountered Hayao Miyazak with his masterwork "Spirited Away," and I was blown away by the pure imagination and genius of his work.

Nothing possibly could've prepared me for the stroke of genius that was to come when I first watched "Castle In the Sky." This isn't just the very best of his work that I've seen, it's one of the very best animated films ever made.

Laputa has slightly rockier storytelling than the other Ghibli films and is much slower paced, but it's none the less worth a watch. With breathtaking visuals and more creativity and imagination than most movies.

A classic. The best Ghibli film. The intro: excelent, wonderfull images. And maybe: the best japan film of the decade. This movie is art and maybe: maybe, maybe... the best film japanese in the history. Perfect score!!!!!
A beautiful and fantastic journey. One of my all time favorites.

Interesting setup but lack of focus and engagement ruins this.

A young girl, Sheeta, escapes from the clutches of some mysterious pirate-like villains.  She ends up in a small village and is befriended by young boy, Pazu.  However, the villains track them down, as do a variety of other people who seem keen to get their hands on the girl, and soon Sheeta and Pazu are fleeing for their lives...

Pretty much your standard Hayao Miyazaki movie: intriguing and original setup, making the first few scenes quite interesting, followed by random, unfocused plot development and lack of character depth or development.  Just becomes a mindless adventure story without any point.

Animation is so-so.  You can't put this down to being made in the 1980s - Disney films of the 1940s and 50s had better animation.

The linear, rambling storyline and lack of thinking required should make this ideal for kids, though the long duration of the movie and jumbled plot might be too much for their concentration spans.  This is certainly not a movie for intelligent adults.

This is my favourite anime film yet. Right off the bat, I thought to myself, "Okay, here is a plot I can get behind." A very simple story with two main characters you can relate with and like right from the start. Exciting action with magical lore you'd find in something like Kingdom Hearts. This film is also beautiful. The world is full of great colours and great landscapes. If you are interested in anime, this is a good one to start with. It's very very good!

Behind Spirited Away, this is the best studio Ghibili film I've seen so far. The imagination of the creators is the key to this and a lot more of these films. They are so original that you are stuck in a trance-like state throughout waiting to see what the next weird genial images will be freak you out next.
Just good all around awesome you should see it movie
Entertaining, beautiful and heartwarming. Typically brilliant Ghibli fare.
I give this a 97/A+.
LOVED this movie recommend to ALL!

One of the most ambitious, adventurous, breathtaking anime films I've seen in my lifetime! It's heartwarming, hilarious, but, most of all, full of courage and heart. Hayao Miyazaki's "Castle in the Sky" proves animated films should be taken seriously due to their unlimited possibilities and imagination. An animated story set in a detailed fantasy world of an ancient mining town mixed with futuristic flying machines that is truly fascinating. One of writer/director Hayoa Miyazaki's best films, this movie delivers an exceptional example of Japanese animation. Usually the english dubs are hard to withstand most times with anime, but in this movie the voice acting is actually pretty well done. The beautiful animation that this film has is truly a sight to behold, and is just really enjoying to watch. The ideas shown in the story are really appealing, and in my opinion is a must watch for everyone.

A masterful work of art, Castle in the Sky fills audiences young and old with more emotion and empathy than most beloved characters today. Amazing visuals, colors, characters, design, and a masterful score help transform this animated movie into a masterpiece. A tear or two may escape, but the story will stick with you well past the credits, and maybe when you look up into the clouds.
One of the most fantastical of the Studio Ghibli films. Having a very entertaining cast, a great sense of adventure and fun, has some great animation and action, and very well written.

Stop it self. You can't be a sky pirate. You don't even want to be a sky pirate. Stop wanting to be a sky pirate.

I think I had seen this film before, but I didn't really remember much about it when watching it this morning. Full of adventure and wonder and all of the beautiful artistry you'd expect from auteur Hayao Miyazaki, Castle in the Sky is an absolutely wonderful and brilliant film that deserves all the praise its received. Miyazaki is one of the most talented storytellers in history when it comes to creating unique and complex worlds, and bringing the audience into them without confusion or disorientation. In Castle in the Sky we are dropped into the world of air pirates, a hidden floating city, and a mystical gem, and we never miss a beat. You are just excited to be on this adventure with these characters, and you can't wait to see what happens next. 

From the beautiful animation to the wonderful and complex performances from the 1998 voice cast, Castle in the Sky is one of the best adventure films of all time. With a Spielberg-esque approach to wonder and adventure, Miyazaki unfolds every moment of this story. You are along for the ride with Pazu and Sheeta as they search for Laputa, and you really begin to care about them as you go. You experience every moment of beauty and amazement with them, but you also feel the fear and excitement that comes with the real danger they experience.

Miyazaki is so great at creating these big moments throughout the film that you can't help but feel like you're watching something more than animation. But he's also so perfect at creating the small character moments that you forget you're not watching real people on screen. All of these characters feel like flesh and blood people, and that is such an accomplishment for an animated feature. I hope that parents continue to bring their children into the world of Miyazaki films, because these beautiful adventures should be enjoyed throughout time.

The first Studio Ghibli movie may not have such a strong message like the other ones I watched, but I really felt like a kid again while I watched it. It's just a lot of fun.
Also the steampunk theme is pretty great.
Miyazaki indeed brings life's lessons surrealistically.

A beautiful, enthralling adventure amongst the clouds. Great design, great story, fun characters, and seemingly limitless creativity, it's as much as you'd expect from a Miyazaki film. My only gripe is Sheeta's inability to pick an accent. But other than that, it is definitely worth checking out.
rad movie. dug the chase sequence bits

This is once again very entertainning, brilliant, astonishing, and so much fun movie. The music to the story everything this movie has works!! Little comedy threw out but works. Story is super good and will have you on your knees beginning for more! Miyazaki just can't let you down in this movie!

Laputa: Castle in the Sky is the first Ghibli film I saw that got me excited to view further works from the studio. 'Castle in the Sky' is a fun story, within a fun steampunk setting, with fun characters, and... yea its tons of fun.
i really liked this, the voice acting was ok, but the story and whimsy of the whole mise en scene were wonderful.
Castle in the Sky slows down in the 2nd half, but picks up quickly to continue its wild and fun ride with stunning animation and like able characters by great voice work.
An interesting and often dark mishmash of Western and Japanese stories, and one of Ghibli's best.
What a joy to find a children's film that isn't dumbed down!
This is one of the most beautiful movies I've seen in a while. Stunning animation, perfect casting, great score and a fun story. Easily the best movie from Hayao Miyazaki.
Hayao does it again and this time with a movie that can challenge Howl's moving castle for the second best of his historic franchise.

Review In A Nutshell:

Studio Ghibli established itself in 1985 and produced their first film a year after; that film was Castle in the Sky. The film was a message to not only the audiences and competing animated studios of Japan, but to the whole world, that they are a force to be reckoned with. Many critics and fans by now have spoken out their adoration for this film, with some claiming it to be the best from both the studio and the director, Hayao Miyazaki. I felt it comes off a bit short in being perfect, but it possesses such a large amount of positive qualities, that I couldn't help but fall in love with it.

The film's plot is not as complicated as I thought it would be, it actually is quite simple to follow and the film doesn't spend too much time in explaining itself to its audience. Miyazaki, who also wrote the screenplay for this film, sees his audience as capable beings that are able to think for themselves, and not needing someone to spoon-feed them in order for them to be satisfied. He has so much faith in his own work that it allows the film to come off as layered and internally complex. The themes and subject of the film brings in ideas that were prominent during this time in cinema, artificial intelligence and extra-terrestrials, the latter being delivered in a more metaphorical form. It was clear to me that Miyazaki was influenced by Close Encounters of the Third Kind as many of the film's scenes and ideas feel similar, just written and directed at a more ambiguous way. It never felt like he was completely ripping off Spielberg's ideas as the events that unfold don't happen with similar precision, it comes off more like a respective homage. Environmentalism has been a common theme in Studio Ghibli films, and this film promotes it beautifully as it doesn't shove it down the audience's throat; for it to be apparent, it is required by the viewers to look beyond the film's basic narrative and search for the film's heart. Also, was I the only one who picked up a feeling of Star Wars in the film's characters, particularly the core antagonist Muska, who comes off like a Darth Vader figure; maybe this was just me.

Castle in the Sky is arguably Studio Ghibli's and Miyazaki's most adventurous and expansive film. The feeling of intimacy is very minimal here and is usually only found in minor character developmental moments with the two leading protagonists. The sense of romance is certainly there but it doesn't reach to a point where it takes over the tone and atmosphere of the film. The film remains on point with its fascination and adventure towards Laputa. Throughout the film, a sense of magic and wonderment fills the story and its characters, which is a quality that is expected from a Miyazaki film. Castle in the Sky remains appealing to an extensive range of audiences as everybody can enjoy an adventure film as it allows us to escape from the simplicity and dullness of life, while at the same time this film features themes and characters that people can easily be fascinated with. I see a lot of myself in Pazu, fascinated by the unknown and determined to find answers. My fascination is driven with selfish intent as I have no agenda to gain a sense of financial profit or political control, I simply just want to know and understand.

My issue with this film lies on the slight drop in quality during the middle section of the film, particularly when the two characters are on the pirate ship. These scenes felt too stagnant and lacking in effectiveness in its attempt of creating a tender atmosphere between the two leading characters. When you compare it to the first and final act of the film, it lacks the emotional impact or intensity that bookends were able to offer. The first act of the film delivers humorous and entertaining sequences that keeps their audiences engages, while also providing small moments of character development. The final act of the film delivers a sense of intensity and threat that lets the lives of the characters feel on the line. If the middle section of the film had that certain quality that made it stand out then I would have adored the hell out of this film and give it a perfect score.

I was truly impressed with the film's visuals, particularly since this film was animated in the 80s, featuring exhilarating action sequences and breathtaking backdrops that could easily have someone completely lose them into the world and story. The film spends very little time during the ground of the earth and instead characters are found in the air, either via an aircraft or the actual castle itself. Clouds and blue skies dominate the scenery, allowing the film to create a sense of magic from elements that are familiar.

The film's musical score is maybe Joe Hisaishi's safest effort. A lot of the time throughout this, it was like watching a Disney film. This isn't necessarily a negative thing as it achieves in creating that sense of wonderment and magic that Miyazaki was going for. Hisaishi understands that Castle in the Sky contains a plot that is universally appealing and he supports that through his score. When comparing this to his other works, it may not rank on top but I have yet to be disappointed with his work, so even if this was his least appealing score, it is still heads and shoulders above the thousands of musical scores produced during the entire history of cinema.

Castle in the Sky comes so close in reaching the perfection that is Princess Mononoke, but its troubling middle section prevented it from being so. If one wants to experience an unforgettable adventure then go see this film.

An action oriented Ghibli- Miyazaki movie. As always, the studio and the master did not dissapoint. Castle in the Sky is his take on action movie, in a magical fantasy setting, which will inspire any artists on any field. The storytelling and visual designs are so great, combine that with all the details in mechanical designs and movements, and you got a creative time of your life.

It's similar to a lot of Miyazaki's other work, but it has a lot of emotion and careful direction to help it stand out among his legendary filmography. It's creative, and while it might not be everyone's cup of tea, it's pretty enjoyable.

Hayao does it again with this beautifully animated adventure that doesn't give up the action, comedy, etc. Its a almost perfect movie from Hayao, that's one of the best he's ever made. The epic adventure tells the story of two kids, who meet up when Sheeta falls out of the sky. The movie is about getting to the epic floating city Laputa, which is the home of a ancient race that had technology far superior to anyone. Its almost like Atlantis, which had advance technology, far superior to anything during its time. The movie shows how power can make people go crazy. If you love these kinds of movies, I highly recommend. If you don't, then I still recommend it. My brother hates these movie, but actually enjoyed this one. Its a fun filled adventure. Overall its one of Hayo's greatest and one of the best animated movie ever. 9.4

Perhaps the only Ghibli feature you could accurately call a "romp." This is a clear, no strings attached adventure movie, and a really really good one at that. Miyazaki borrows heavily from his excellent TV series Future Boy Conan - which probably won't mean anything to most people - but obviously condenses the length to a reasonable running time. Overall it's just a lot of fun.

Fun Fact: Laputa has been removed from the U.S. title because of an unfortunate Spanish translation. Less fun: the U.S. blu-ray/DVD release uses dubtitles; subtitles that reflect the English dialog, which has subtle, but occasionally nauseating changes. Only an issue if one prefers to watch in Japanese, which I do. Though not an issue if you speak Japanese (I only know a few words).

I think I need to give this one a second chance at some point but on my first watch I thought it stalled a few times and took longer than it needed to tell the story. It still had amazing visuals and what not so it's by no means terrible. Miyazaki fans should love it!

03. Laputa: Castle In The Sky

As the first official release from the company, this Gulliver's Travels inspired masterpiece completes every trademark criteria on Ghibli's report card. Telling the coming of age story about a young boy and girl who are racing against pirates to locate a legendary floating castle, it's overflowing with action packed sequences and magical crystals without shying away from their signature sense of humour or their classic moral lessons, teaching against greed and power and war and other such bad things that bad people do. Not to mention the steampunk design is probably the most impressively executed from the studio to this very date, the Laputan robots alone standing as one of the greatest character designs in the Ghibli arsenal, easily. It's no wonder, then, that in an 80,000 strong audience poll, Castle in the Sky was the second highest-ranked animated film ever, and currently holds a 94% 'Fresh' rating on Rotten Tomatoes. 

To read the rest of my 'Worst to Best: Studio Ghibli' list, click here: http://juicenothing.blogspot.co.uk/2014/06/worst-to-best-studio-ghibli.html

Magical, mystical and uplifting are words I'd easily attribute to the works of Hayao Miyazaki and Castle in the Sky is no different.  This steampunk inspired film filled with adventure, fun, laughs and a poignant message regarding nature, exploitation and government is truly a delight to behold.

(*** )  Another above-average animation tale from Studio Ghibli.  Not quite as powerful or emotional as some of his other tales, but this one has merits all its own.  It matches many of Miyazaki's constantly recurring themes, giving another look at how humanity plays a role in the progression of nature and ecology.

Castle in the Sky falls somewhere in the middle of Miyazaki's varying maturity levels.  While certainly not a children's movie specifically, it isn't too frightening for the young ones, with great scenes of peril being the most shocking imagery.  It's on par with most present-day American family films in this respect.  Additionally it sports a more standard plot structure than most Studio Ghibli productions, with relatively familiar characters and goals.  Nonetheless, there is still a level of imagination here which seems to escape Hollywood animators, or rather I should say Hollywood writers.  Not to say that American writers are less talented, only that they are constrained by a modern studio system which demands a more formulaic approach.

This may be why Castle in the Sky didn't appeal to me as much as other Miyazaki projects.  It doesn't carry the same sweeping imagination which entices you into its world.  In fact for much of the first hour I found myself daydreaming and losing interest in much of the action.  The scenery is worthy of as much praise as other action greats like Nausicaa and Mononoke, but it isn't nearly as viscerally involving.

What may be most praiseworthy about this film is the reveal of the actual castle in question, and the secrets that lie therein.  I won't divulge the details, but I feel like it was brilliantly executed and the stark contrast of areas within the mythical Laputa plays perfectly into Miyazaki's vision of man vs. nature.  Beauty alongside incredible technology and an ancient people who hoped to find harmony between the two, while nearly ruling the world in the process.  This is a world only Miyazaki could create, and it's definitely a fun one in which to escape.

Another female protagonist walks this world.  Like many others, she is somewhat clueless about her place in the world and is simply trying to accomplish an epic goal while never cutting corners by hurting others.  This character type which Miyazaki loves to use is one of the most inspirational parts of his filmmaking, serving as a wonderful role model for young audiences.  The male character in this film is also a pure hero, who gives his full devotion to friends as well as adventure.

In summary, Castle in the Sky is a really good film which sadly doesn't have the intoxicating fantasy of some of Studio Ghibli's great productions.  All that aside, it is still a better option than 90% of the CGI slapstick bug-eyed creature films which occupy our silver screens most of the time.

Alrighty, here we go again. I set out to delve into the works of "the Great Miyazaki" about a month ago. So far, I have been extremely disappointed with Spirited Away, I was impressed and often floored by Princess Mononoke, and I was left completely indifferent by Howl's Moving Castle. I started watching Castle in the Sky with the most modest of expectations. I wasn't expecting greatness, but I was also excited to see Miyazaki's take on a swashbuckling story. In the end, I was mostly satisfied. The problems with pacing and narrative continue to force me to marvel at why Miyazaki is esteemed so highly. And yet, the movie does have a host of fun parts while lacking some of the filmmaker's usual pretentiousness. While by no means great, Castle in the Sky does slide in nicely between Howl's Moving Castle and Princess Mononoke as my second favorite Miyazaki movie.

A young girl named Sheeta posses a beautiful crystal. Said crystal has immense power, so obviously, bad people want it for themselves. Sheeta winds up in the care of young Pazu. He has a dream of one day seeing the floating city of Laputa. Oddly enough, Sheeta's crystal has the ability to make her float as well. So with sky pirates and crooked government agents hot on their trail, Pazu and Sheeta set out to reach Laputa.

The most glaring issue with Castle in the Sky revolves around its story. Number one, the movie is far too long at 125 minutes. It's disappointing to say, but this movie is actually pretty boring at times. The pacing is off, making parts of the movie very dull. Even the "grand finale" was plodding. Which leads to number two, the movie's payoff is extremely weak. The first two acts of the movie definitely had me intrigued to see the floating city. And since the movie is so lengthy, there's this long (and sometimes tedious) buildup to the third act. But then once the movie finally arrives at the floating city, it honestly has nothing to say. It's probably trying to say something really deep about saving the trees and whatnot, but the execution is massively disappointing. And the ending itself is just atrocious. The movie has no idea what to do with itself when it comes to wrapping everything up. So instead of providing real closure, the movie just flails off the the side a little bit, then ends. Not what you would expect from a "master filmmaker."

For these reasons, Castle in the Sky definitely has the most wasted potential of any Miyazaki movie I've seen. In a story with sky pirates, massive hand cannons, steampunk flying ships, and a floating city (!), we don't even get an entirely entertaining two hours!? All the pieces of a great movie are in place. I have no complaints about the story, characters, action, universe, and so forth. But most of that is squandered with poor pacing and the lame third act ... and all the fault rest in the director/screenwriter. In all fairness, this was only Miyazaki's 2nd full movie. But then again, he makes the exact same mistakes almost twenty years later in Howl's Moving Castle. 

At least this movie does have the pieces of a great film. The story is the most "swashbuckling" idea I've seen from Miyazaki. The supporting characters are very distinctive. The action is pretty amazing when it does show up. Miyazaki's eye for visuals is still fully intact. He creates yet another splendid world! I do love the steampunk elements, and I'm always happy to see airborne pirates!

The cast does an adequate job. James Van Der Beek plays Pazu just as he should be played. I was very disappointed that both Pazu and Sheeta were completely void of character development. For that matter, there really isn't any meaningful development for any of the characters. Anna Paquin plays Sheeta. For the entire movie, I was trying to place her voice. She's got that very singular way of talking. At any rate, she is just fine as Sheeta, considering how unoriginal the character is. And speaking of which, with the exception of Princess Mononoke, Miyazaki continues to create really uninspired main characters. Both the character, and character design of Pazu and Sheeta remains wholly bland. They are the standard movie hero and heroine. Nothing sets them apart.

The supporting cast does well enough. Cloris Leachman is the most interesting as Dola, the pirate captain. The entire pirate crew is probably the most interesting bunch of supporting characters Miyazaki has ever dreamed up. Mark Hamill plays the villain, Colonel Muska. After achieving commercial success in Star Wars, Hamill won critical acclaim for his vocal performance as The Joker in Batman the Animated Series. Here, he doesn't stand out in any way. If I didn't see his name in the credits, I would have never thought it was Hamill. 

At the risk of sounding like a broken record, I must reaffirm that Joe Hisaishi does, in fact, provide yet another A+ musical score! When watching a Miyazaki movie, I can count on two things as surefire hits: the animation and visuals will be stunning, and Hisaishi will provide a splendid score. And so he does! It isn't quite as memorable as his other work (that I've heard), but it still does its job, and does it extremely well. 

Castle in the Sky is at both times the most frustrating, and the second best Miyazaki movie I've seen. If he had capitalized on all the potential in this film, it probably would have been better than Princess Mononoke. But through poor screenwriting, Castle in the Sky is knocked down to "only slightly better than Howl's Moving Castle" status. If there's one overarching flaw I've found in all Miyazaki movies, its that he simply cannot write a satisfying third act. Believe it or not, Spirited Away is the only example where the third act is better than what came before it. So at the end of the day, given its potential for greatness, Castle in the Sky is a solid movie that ultimately feels like a glaring waste of great ideas. 

"A king without compassion does not deserve a kingdom." 7/10

A great and fantastic movie. I'm not usually an anime fan but there is an exception for this one. I really enjoyed the voices they used especially Mark Hamill as the villain. Miyazaki is a versatile artist who can make just as many thought-provoking stories as lighter ones. This one ranks among the latter, a very delightful animation that has its share of sillier moments but makes up for them with a lot of fun and adventure.

A wonderful animated sci-fi story that is colorful and creative. I didn't find it quite as charming as Howl's Moving Castle, but I enjoyed it more than the other Miyazaki movies I've seen. I actually enjoyed James Van Der Beek's English voice dubbing as it seemed to match up well with his character. Paquin....not so much.

(1989) Castle In The Sky
JAPAN ANIMATION/ FANTASY

  I originally couldn't get into this film the first time I saw it, but started to like it after my second viewing since the set up is not something I'm usually accustomed to which regards a teenage girl named Sheeta and her crystal pendant.  Written and directed by Hayao Miyazaki which the time is during the late 1900's or somewhere along there, and a group of pirates on flying pods with huge insect wings are sabotaging a huge state-of-the-art airplane blimp that looks very futuristically advanced.   Anyways, the guy keeping her held up is also bad otherwise, Sheeta would not have knocked him out with a vase and everyone seems to be after her.  So she steps out of the blimp and falls making her faint but the pendent she's wearing around her neck saves her by floating her down very gently- similar to what a balloon would do.  The boy Pazu is there and catches her and doesn't know what to make of it. We, the viewers are also curious about it's movie's title "Castle In the Sky" and what does she as well as her pendent have to do with it, and it regards some mythical legend regarding a castle that's been seen floating around but has never been discovered.  Is this legend just a hoax or is it really a reality which regards Sheeta's past.   For the movie explains how it may be  possible for anything to float in the first place and it has a lot to do with the pendant she is wearing.

I thought Anna Paquin did an awesome job with Sheeta but I can't say the same for James Van der Beek voicing for Pazu. Aforementioned, I'm not accustomed to director Miyazaki including very evil characters since I really believe that a leopard can't change his spots and he sort of depends on fate to take care of itself when it would've been better if he doesn't even include any evil characters at all.

While it's largely claimed that Spirited Away is Hayao Miyazaki's finest achievement, I must respectfully disagree. Although I have not yet seen Princess Mononoke which many say is a very formidable contender, I think Laputa is definitely one of the best studio ghibli films out there. Treading a fine line between his epic adventures (Nausicca, Howl's Moving Castle) and his gentler dramas (like my personal favorite My Neighbor Totoro), Hayao Miyazaki crafts an influential tale that is heartwarming, thrilling, and thoughtful often all at the same time. Not a film to be missed.

An earlier entry from master animator Hayao Miyazaki that captures the wonder & adventure of two children in search for a castle & civilization in the sky..

No human has ever been able to reach Laputa (Castle in the Sky) but the girl carries an item & heritage that can get them there.

Filled with mystery & terrific animation, it truly is an exceptional film. An engrossing picture that is a delight for children & adults alike.
This was one of the only other Miyazaki films I actually saw as a kid and like those movies it actually gets better with age.

The ending (literally) collapses--not from the weight of a soaring castle but from a main villain that, thought admirably voiced by Mark Hamill in the English re-dub, simply isn't very interesting.  In hindsight, Miyazaki's aerial motifs also just don't resonate the way they do in, say, the superior "Porco Rosso".  I enjoyed the first hour immensely, but I would have enjoyed seeing a bit more of the titular castle and its awe-inspiring visuals.  Not to mention the movie's primary themes of "man vs. nature" and "abuse of power" either wallow in cliche or become muddled altogether in the final stretch.  Oh, and Anna Paquin's shifting accents are also pretty distracting, migrating between American, British, and Australian throughout the film.  Van Der Beek and Cloris Leachman are probably the standouts.  Not the worst Studio Ghibli movie, but it definitely ranks in the middle.

Lets start off Ghibli month with, Castle in the Sky or Laputa, which is what is called in the Japanese version.
And it is not only a good movie, its a great movie, but...

OK, before I bring up the only bad news about this film, lets talk about the good stuff, cause honestly there's a lot. While I was watching the film, I felt like I was watching a film that I generally had only seen for the first time, which not also brought a nostalgia mindset, but had also decided to try the best it could to keep it, and you know what, it did it well, it did it very well.

The plot goes as we see a girl named Sheeta being captured by the "evil government" so to speak for helping them find a mysterious floating island known as Laputa, and then its being intervened by a group of pirates who are there to take her "amulet" an object that has mystical powers that grants access to the floating island which is said to have hidden treasures. Among the capture she falls out in the sky and is picked up by a boy named Pazu who also wants to go to Laputa to prove that his father wasn't a liar, because he had previously went there. Then the boy gets mixed up and its a race to figure out how to keep Sheeta safe from all of this and to figure out the truth behind Laputa and why it was put there and left there to begin with. Thus its a battle between the pirates, the main characters, the evil whatchamacallit, its a TON.

Let me just start off with right now, the film animation is gorgeous, this is one of the most artistic pieces of animation, I've ever seen, even for 1989. Every colorful shot looks like I'm watching a picture of a beautiful painting, the cool blue colors of contrast in the sky, the warm contrast in the white clouds, the background, the foreground, everything about the animation is top-notch, and its absolutely done well.

Then you have the main characters, their very likable their very curious, they use their heads throughout the majority of the film whenever it comes to science and the unknown, the side characters are very likable and funny, the villain, will get to him later.
The music is very memorable, Joe Hisaishi (Hee-saw-ee-shee) or (Hee-saeye-shee) whatever his last name is pronounced has done a very good job bringing the music to life with brass trumpets, Japanese choir and beautifully orchestrated pieces. And the story to the film is brilliant.

Why didn't it get 5 stars?
Well, I have to say that there only two problems with the movie, first off is the English dub, its not that voices actors do a terrible job, but they chose adults for the dubbing of this movie, and its not half bad its just not great though. Its not the writing, well some of it, but that's not the focus, its the differences between the Japanese version and the Disney version.

When this film was released, it was released in 2003 in America, and that's a long time before America ever got to see this film strike rich here. And did it strike rich here? Not quite, it would be a while before Ghibli ever got to have their films sent to the US for dubbing, and well, will get to that later. But that's still not the problem.

The problem is is the fact that they changed a few things from the original Japanese version, for instance, one of the things that they did was that they added music into the quiet moments, because apparently for whatever stupid reason it was, Disney thought that kids would get bored if nothing was going on. That's one problem.

The second problem is the villain, who is a little weak and very forgettable name-wise, I mean I even remember having to go on a wiki article just to find out who the bad guy is, and yeah, when you do that, and you forget, it can be a little distracting. In fact, I watched the English dub just for the heck of it, and the only thing that I could remember about the villain was that it was voiced by Mark Hamill, that was it. I didn't know why or how, but that's all I could think of. Is there much change in the Japanese version? Aside from the voice actor, surprisingly, no, its not that the villain is a bad villain he's just not particularly memorable, I mean he does something, but, he's just not the best I've seen. But other than that, that's the only other problems I had. There were a few minor problems with the side characters, for example there is one character that is just in one scene and gone for the rest of the movie, and I ask the question, where did he come from? What's his background, what's his story? I don't know, and it kills me that I can't figure it out. But other than that, that's the only problems.

Is the movie good? Heck yes! Should you watch the Disney version? Heck no. In fact, I'd rather you just stick with the original source which is the Japanese version. But that's just me though, I can't stop you from watching the Disney version even if I wanted to. What would I give the Disney dub, well aside from the differences with music, sound effects, the voice acting, probably a 4 * out of 5. And even with that score its still a great film, I just would like to see the film re-dubbed if it were possible and kept in its original form.

But with the Japanese version, on the other hand, the characters, the memorable music, the animation, the writing, the ingenuity of it all. I have to give it a 4.5 out of 5 *'s.

If you want to see this movie, check it out and decide for yourself, but I would implore you to watch the Japanese version :3. LOL

More Studio Ghibli movies are on the way! Stay tuned!

bought the dvd when i was 11 but never really got into it like i did with princess mononoke for whatever reason i mean that was my favorite movie for like 7 years. this has aged incredibly well for me. much more action packed, brilliantly animated, and whimsical (though gradually gets more and more serious to great effect) than i remembered so much so that i'm wondering why i've always been so indifferent about it. even under ghibli 1984-2002 standards it's almost top-tier and that's no small compliment. it does drag at points but fuck you

Castle in the Sky felt like the premise of an anime series crammed into a movie.  Miyazaki mad a masterpiece here and truly showed the world an emotional story with action, treason, adventure, and emotion.

Creative, well-animated, thought-provoking, unique ... an absolute gem.

After the huge success of Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind, it's writer and director, Hayao Miyazaki, would go on to establish the now famous Studio Ghibli with fellow animator Isao Takahata in 1985. One year after it's establishment, Miyazaki would direct the first movie officially released under the Studio Ghibli name, known as Laputa: Castle in the Sky (simply renamed Castle in the Sky in later releases). Also written by Miyazaki, Castle in the Sky is a wonderfully made movie, filled to the brim with fun action scenes and hilarious jokes. 

According to Castle in the Sky's backstory, human civilization built huge cities floating above the clouds before a catastrophe destroyed all but one city, Laputa. Viewed mostly as a legend by civilization down on the ground, nobody is quite sure if it is real or a hoax. One such person is Pazu, a young boy whose father had searched for Laputa himself. One day, Pazu is heading to work when he discovers a strange blue light falling slowly from the sky. Upon investigating, Pazu finds the most unexpected of things: a young girl.

Pazu soon discovers that the girl's name is Sheeta, and she has apparent ties to Laputa, which Pazu has his own fascination with. As the two grow closer as friends, a man by the name of Muska and a group of air-pirates, led by a woman named Dola, both of whom were chasing Sheeta in the film's opening sequence, resume their chase for Sheeta, more specifically the necklace she wears around her neck. As Pazu and Sheeta attempt to escape these two groups, they are sucked into a grand adventure that unleashes the secrets of Laputa itself. 

Miyazaki's tale in Castle in the Sky is a very whimsical adventure full of adventure and excitement. Like his previous movie, Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind, Miyazaki includes themes of environmentalism and war, but they aren't nearly as obvious as they were in Nausicaa. The real strength of Castle in the Sky, however, is the dialogue itself. The screenplay has a good mix of seriousness and humor that works extremely well throughout the entire movie. Although the pacing seems inconsistent, the story and dialogue itself is superb. 

The voice talent is good overall. James Van Der Meek is a delightful voice for Pazu, although he may seem to old for the character. Anna Paquin voices Sheeta, who is just ok overall. She almost seems to jump
back and forth between an attempted American accent and her native Canadian accent, which can seem a bit obnoxious at times. The two actors create amazing chemistry between their two characters though, which is absolutely charming. Also in the cast is Cloris Leachman as a great Dola, and Mark Hamill as Muska, who arguably steals the show with his amazing performance as the primary antagonist.

As Studio Ghibli's first feature film, Castle in the Sky is a huge success. Miyazaki's original story is action packed and humorous, allowing it to be enjoyed by viewers of all ages. The voice talent is solid, particularly Mark Hamill's menacing villain, and the animation is beautiful. The movie may have flaws within its pacing and certain elements of its voice cast, but overall, Castle in the Sky is a solid Miyazaki movie. With two fantastic movies under his belt, Hayao Miyazaki started his career with a bang, and Castle in the Sky was just the beginning.
