Continuing my Hayao Miyazaki film streak... here is my review of Castle in the Sky. Sheeta is a confused young girl on the run from pirates and the military. She finds safety with another orphan, Pazu. He lives in a mining town full of very humble and helpful neighbors. Pazu and Sheeta become friends immediately. Pazu helps her get away from the wannabe kidnappers.

Sheeta has a mysterious necklace that seems to assist her whenever she's in dangerous situations. Pazu's father had a fascination with trying to discover the floating city of Laputa. Sheeta learns of her heritage later on and discovers she is a princess of Laputa. After many struggles and a great adventure the two orphans find their way to the floating city. Laputa is a magnificent city. It has a great tree at the center with roots running deep. It was also a city of advanced technology. Laputa was an interesting combination of nature and science. 

The music was so wonderful while soaking in the scenery. Castle in the Sky is yet another beautiful movie by Hayao Miyazaki. The focus for this movie is more around friendship versus family. For me, it really described how friends can become our family.  The pirates seem like the bad guys at the beginning of the movie but they soon become allies. The "captain" and mother of the many boys is a very strong female character. All of her sons are very goofy yet obidient. The fathers appearance reminded me of Doctor Eggman from Sonic the Hedgehog. This movie isn't as carefree as My Neighbor Totoro or Kiki's Delivery Service. The story is still amazing as well as the visual effects and music. It's still safe for children to watch but definitely a little bit more serious as far as the plot is concerned. I absolutely loved the robots!
Inspiring visuals, storytelling and characters. I loved the fantasy!

"Castle in the Sky" is considered to be the first ever film released from this filmmaker (Hayao Miyazaki) and to be perfectly honest, it's a sheer masterpiece in storytelling and in it's visuals. There were portions that actually made me tear up, just listening to the music along with the scenery, which was brilliant beyond belief. The American voice acting fits very well into the Dubbed version and the overall atmosphere is just so loveable. Many films have definitely been influenced by this, and I would be shocked if they denied that, because the filmmaking (mostly in post) is breathtaking. I have absolutely no complaints about this film whatsoever. It is funny, well written, well directed, and beautifully animated. With no flaws in sight, this film is incredible!

Castle in the Sky is quite confusing; its sleek plot overlaps with the rough animation, but it is enjoyable and the characters are engaging and believable. The Japanese animation business once again creates a masterpiece, unlike Little Norse Prince, for instance.
Original and memorable, with great action sequences and a smart script.

This movie is quite different of Miyazayi's next works. In this movie the director let us  see what he think about politics. It is not a japanese topic but a german or russian topic made by a japanese thinker.

A majestic adventure. I don't like to repeat myself but it's hard not to use the words "creative" or "imaginative" to explain Miyazaki films. It's a very heart-warming movie that makes you care about the characters through superb writing and beautiful presentation. This movie makes me happy and it leaves me wanting more.
Hayao Miyazaki is a genius; want proof? Then watch Castle in The Sky. This masterpiece by Miyazaki is best at every level.

Laputa is the second film ever made by Studio Ghibli and is one of the most magical adventures they've ever created. It's a beautiful animated film that pleases both adults and children. For a film made in 1986, the quality of animation throughout is extraordinary. While it isn't flawless, it is still one of the very best creations from the masterful mind of Hayao Miyazaki.

Everything in the film revolves around a floating castle in the sky named Laputa. The main character is Shita (Anna Paquin), a little girl who possesses an ominous crystal with the power to make her float to safety. After she escapes being captured by a strange man who seeks the crystal, she floats down safely into the arms of a young man named Patsu (James Van Der Beek). Together, they run from pirates, the army, and all sorts of strange people. Only one thing is certain: they are all seeking the path to Laputa and whatever secrets and treasures lies within.

One thing that instantly stands out in this film is the magnificent score by Joe Hisaishi. He has made some marvellous music for Studio Ghibli. Laputa stands up there as one of his very best. It sets the tone of the film and really brings emotion into the story. The animation is also breathtaking, considering the time the film was made. It may not stand up to the standards of today's animation, but its beauty is still something to behold.

Cloris Leachman was the standout among the voice actors. She was fantastic as 'Dola', the leader of the pirates. There are many amazing characters throughout the Studio Ghibli movies, and she would be up there with the best. Anna Paquin's New Zealander accent was exotic and certainly set the film apart from most. I don't mean to offend anyone from NZ, but after prolonged exposure to her voice I became irritated. I had the same feelings towards the voice actor of Patsu, who grained on my patience too.

I loved the movie to bits. It truly set a benchmark for animated films back in its day. My small synopsis did not do the story justice, for it really is a remarkable tale. The music, animation, and story combine to create one of the greatest animated movies of all time. Although it isn't the best of Hayao Miyazaki (That honor would fall to either Spirited Away, Howl's Moving Castle or Princess Mononoke), it is still one of the best animated movies of all time.

One of the best movies of Hayao Miyazaki. Such a beautiful movie, about a Princess, her home and her past. The idea of a floating castle, stunned me! Loved the scenery and animation. Pazu, was the best character in the movie. This was yet another epic Studio Ghibli movie, filled with suspense, drama and a joy of being young.

This movie has a very imaginative and fun world that lends itself well to some beautifully animated scenery (though the animation quality on this movie admittedly isn't nearly as high as Miyazaki's other work), the writing and characters are both very enjoyable and the music by Joe Hisaishi is brilliant as always. The main faults with this movie are in the English dub, which is hit and miss: James Van Der Beek as Pazu is very unfitting considering the character's design and intended age, Anna Paquin as Sheeta and Cloris Leachman as Dola are enjoyable enough and even if it is extremely easy to point him out, Mark Hamill does a fantastic job voicing Muska. Overall, a very fun movie either in the original Japanese or with the English dub but the English dub on this movie is probably the weakest I've seen for a Ghibli film despite Mark Hamill's great performance.

Totally involving, even though the english dubbed version contains too much one-liner fillers, the vision of the animation and the tenderness and adventurous spirit of the characters makes it poignant and captivating to watch. Coupled with eco-friendly theme that resonates throughout, this movie is typical Miyazaki melodrama that lifts up your spirits.

I think it was great! Lovely,beautiful and interesting! The reason why i don't give it a full 4 stars is because the ending was weak. Why he didn't picture or something the castle and prove his dad's rumors about Laputa and clean his name? I thought it was his dream...  the movie could be better but that doesn't mean that it's bad. I recommend it to everyone with good imagination!

A pair of kids go hunting for a mythical floating city. Meanwhile, crack-pot sky pirates and villainous government types are hot on their tale. The characters aren't as fleshed out as you would hope, nor is there much to the story. But the focus is on adventure and adventure it delivers in spades.

A great anime film, one of Hayao Miyazaki's best, and probably the most humorous. It has it all, adventure, romance and lots of comedy, especially Captain Dola's goofy crew.     Visually it's very easy on the eye. A classic and great for the family to enjoy.

One of Miyazaki's masterpieces.  Excluding the memorable characters, stunning animation, beautiful theme song, and great messages, the movie is beautifully emotional.

This might be one of the coolest and most interesting stories I've ever seen. The concept of this movie is right up my alley. Mysterious floating castle in the sky that has been undiscovered and passed into legend? Doesn't get much more interesting than that. Plus, as per usual, Ghibli animates the films miraculously and does a great job with character development. The one thing about Ghibli that makes it so great is that they take time to develope characters and really flesh out the story and make it the best it can be. There's no mentality of, "lets just skip adding depth to the story to get to the explosions and cool anime cliches." That's what makes Ghibli films the best, this film has all those fantastic elements and combining them with such an awesome fantasy environment makes this one of my favorite Ghibli films.

Disjointed in it's story line, as many Japanese anime films are, Castle in the Sky is nonetheless very creative. I always feel a little icky when I hear Dawson's voice however and as the voice behind the main character, you feel very icky by the end.

A really great movie with a unique plot and unique characters. One problem is that it is rather long and at some points may seem to drag on a bit. Not the best movie for young audiences as it may be too long for their attention spans.

A rare jewel. There are not many animated films out there as good as "Castle in the Sky". Everything from the music, characters, animation, and story are perfectly crafted. "Castle in the Sky" is a wonderful film and I want to show it to as many people as possible.
This has to be the most emotional of all Miyazaki's works, very moving music too

A beautifully animated, highly imaginative whimsical tale, with two likeable protagonists in Sheeta (Keiko Yokozawa) and Pazu (Mayumi Tanaka). For the most part, this is exciting stuff, albeit a little too long for its own purpose.
